<p>
TO <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=joa" rel="met kin colleague">JOSEPH ALSTON</a>.
</p><p>
<a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?city=new york" rel="city">New-York</a>, January 15, <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?year=1801">1801</a>.
</p><p>
MY DEAR SIR,
</p><p>
Your two letters have been received, and gave me great pleasure. We
are about to begin our journey to <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?city=albany" rel="city">Albany</a>. I propose to remain there
till the 10th of February; possibly till the 20th. If you should come
northward, you will find a letter for you in the postoffice of this
city.
</p><p>
The equality of <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=thj" rel="met colleague">Jefferson</a> and Burr excites great speculation and much
anxiety. I believe that all will be well, and that <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=thj" rel="met colleague">Jefferson</a> will be
our president. Your friend,
</p><p>
<a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=aab" rel="me">A. BURR</a>.
</p>
